A8F08352303F4626868EE4BEB8F96C25.description: Organisms have external structures that can vary; e.g., plants may have roots, stems, leaves, flowers, fruit, or other structures animals may have claws, teeth, legs, shells, skins, or other structures

4B8457C91B2844ABB161D1DE19E002E5.description: Organisms are living things that respond to stimuli and include plants, humans, and other animals.

A0CF035178D442F38A964C1022A76270.description: Students analyze organisms and relate external structures to functions.

B9FEDC9F7C6D4CA392E70FA67C41ECEA.description: Living Systems: Understandings of the living world, Earth, and space are deepened by investigating natural systems and their interactions.

428B9A4DAEB2417B8D591F28E942A059.description: Investigate conservation practices in natural and human-made areas.

7CD5200F3F6D43ECABEAEDD70B65DFF9.description: Explain how changes in one system can have impacts on other systems.

D7F0E67F7C7D49AE8D589E1196A87F8D.description: Identify plants and animals that exist in various bodies of water.

F76EF3AE6F3B436496D0EF99105A7503.description: Analyze the interconnectedness of Earth's systems.

537150278609462AAA28A3C45F0EC44F.description: Make connections between human activity and Earth's systems.

E776799294164631964D48BA89A4F2EC.description: Many First Nations, Métis, and Inuit practise traditional methods of conservation, including taking only what is needed.

98BA84A6564142D8874C46FB577F68C1.description: Conservation can impact land, natural resources, and organisms.

DAACBFC6E6CC40D5A1B3A92B421B0386.description: Earth's systems include natural resources that are central to human well-being.

186E778079D1498F8A426B8E83D72BF8.description: Earth's systems are interconnected and can be impacted by small changes.

4CBC9DC9F2744E34892BBF3D3DF67D98.description: Caring for water and water sources is a shared responsibility.

A15A6CBE9AD04561AF8D79A8F86755CE.description: Earth's surface is warmed by the Sun, allowing for life.

4E65A352C9884B62BA09B88B7A13A06E.description: Earth's systems interact with one another, resulting in environments that sustain life.

AE716BCF2D8B4DA6878A42DD9D4B46C7.description: Conservation can be practised through community or global actions, such as use of energy-efficient alternatives; e.g., solar panels, supplying water to support crops (irrigation) and community recycling or composting programs

7D00C2BCF2A1456A8362C9AEEF25BA7F.description: Conservation can be practised through personal actions, including use of electricity; e.g., turning off lights when leaving a room, use of water; e.g., taking shorter showers and reducing waste; e.g., using reusable packaging

F9B0B5FDCD7B430CBC501D81AF19B410.description: First Nations, Métis, and Inuit have a long history with the land that has informed conservation practices and beliefs.

5D6BCDAD15FC43EA87384D207B434987.description: Conservation can involve creating local, provincial, and national parks.

88EF48C3386A4F9EA027AFEC1ABCEF22.description: Conservation practices can be implemented in natural and human-made areas.

C5D941897F664F7E9C137224AE9D3A77.description: Conservation is the preservation and protection of Earth's systems from pollution, depletion, or extinction.

EAEDB93F668540F1B26368A4290E1AF0.description: Natural resources are materials from nature that are used to meet human needs, and include air, water, soil, minerals, metals, forests and organisms

3EE5083E6C2E485F95637A854102C6AC.description: Governments, conservation groups, and First Nations, Métis, and Inuit communities collaborate with Parks Canada to conserve, restore, and protect Canada's natural and cultural heritages through initiatives such as culture camps, science camps, land management and preservation of important sites and cultural centres

3228220473B1428D8D82982BE509C683.description: Changes in one system that can impact another system include changes in number of organisms, food sources, habitat, water distribution and cleanliness and weather patterns

EAF20C97D8334C3887CAA5831B702647.description: First Nations, Métis, and Inuit laws of nature include how nature provides gifts of life and living in harmony with the land

D2478544A6D941A58FB6F163A767425C.description: Laws of nature guide First Nations, Métis, and Inuit in their responsibility to protect water and sources of water.

5F6F4A805364471499F86DF75EF59550.description: First Nations, Métis, and Inuit laws of nature honour water as being sacred because water sustains life.

B09F2617EDD640ED91BB85F2CBC041D6.description: Water provides habitat for many organisms.

3451AFC3481F424A9CAADC261D3B59CF.description: Water is a basic need for plants and animals.

5F9127D9CCB746C9891EF89AB6FC1FD1.description: In Alberta, sunlight is more direct, and the length of daylight is longer, in summer than in winter.

4A5A56B62A8B4B719EB0EDD0BBEC3485.description: The long-term temperature at the equator is warmer than it is at the poles.

D3F811E0526E4E379D5599978572E23F.description: Sunlight is more direct at the equator than at the poles.

116F28B1E834400389EFFE2958B88FEC.description: Organisms require warmth and energy from the Sun to live.

2A39D4F45A834CEE8790A8D83A56C1B3.description: First Nations, Métis, and Inuit hold understandings of Earth systems that sustain life, including that all things are interconnected.

22B2E76DF6314B9C982BFB1E8B00EAFA.description: Earth scientists call Earth's systems the spheres, including the lithosphere, atmosphere, hydrosphere and biosphere

9976A004FB234915AC4F064BFAB0291D.description: Students investigate the systems of Earth and reflect on how their interconnections sustain life.

3F38114C2F1846C8B57CDED07B1994D1.description: Earth Systems: Understandings of the living world, Earth, and space are deepened by investigating natural systems and their interactions.

85641BC765154EA5BD8C066BD61E9630.description: Magnets interact with each other and magnetic material.

7E9D1A007FBF48379C170B2B2E6CAD25.description: Gravity on Earth is a non-contact force that pulls objects toward the ground.

47C359AF43A94A568DFFE19FDD839B3D.description: Non-contact forces occur between objects that are not in direct contact.

BF265D915A4242E2A31641562C4BA466.description: Students investigate how forces can act on objects without contact.
